unnormalised: The sun beat down on Kamala’s back as she surveyed her two acres of land in the village of Shivapur, Maharashtra. Unlike her neighbours, who had embraced the Green Revolution with its promises of high yields through chemical fertilizers and pesticides, Kamala remained steadfast in her commitment to organic farming. Her father, a traditional farmer named Ramchandra, had instilled in her a deep respect for the land and its natural rhythms. He always said, "The soil is our mother, Kamala. Treat her with kindness, and she will nourish you."

Treat her with kindness, and she will nourish you."

unnormalised: Kamala remembers vividly the days when her father used to prepare Jeevamrut, a concoction of cow dung, cow urine, jaggery, gram flour, and soil, fermented together and applied to the fields. The smell was pungent, but the results were undeniable. The soil teemed with life, earthworms wriggling through the earth, enriching it naturally. Now, Kamala carries on that tradition.

unnormalised: “Initially, it was tough,” she admits, wiping sweat from her brow. “The yields were lower compared to the chemically enhanced farms. My neighbours would scoff, saying, ‘Kamala is wasting her time with all this gobar (cow dung) and gaumutra (cow urine).’ Even the local Krishi Vigyan Kendra experts hinted that I should consider adopting modern methods."

unnormalised: However, Kamala persevered. She attended workshops on organic farming techniques conducted by the Navdanya organization, learning about crop rotation, companion planting, and natural pest control. She learned how to make Neem-based pesticides and other organic solutions. Gradually, her yields started to improve. More importantly, the quality of her produce – tomatoes, brinjal, okra, and various leafy greens – was noticeably superior. People from nearby Pune started seeking her out, willing to pay a premium for her organically grown vegetables.

unnormalised: The turning point came when a group of students from the College of Agriculture, Akola, visited her farm as part of a research project. They analyzed her soil and found it to be rich in organic matter and beneficial microbes, far exceeding the levels in conventionally farmed land in the area. Dr. Patil, their professor, was impressed. He presented Kamala's success story at a national conference, highlighting the economic and environmental benefits of organic farming.

unnormalised: Today, Kamala's farm is a model of sustainable agriculture. She earns approximately Rs. 1,50,000 per year from her two acres (approximately 87,120 sq ft). She employs two local women and inspires other farmers in Shivapur to consider transitioning to organic methods. She proves that Ramchandra’s wisdom was right. Her journey hasn't been easy, but she knows that she is not just farming; she is nurturing the land for future generations. The taste of her organically grown tomatoes, bursting with flavour under the warm Maharashtra sun, is proof enough.
